frame.name: Text
frame.definition: <def-root>A <fen>Text</fen> is an entity that contains linguistic, symbolic information on a <fen>Topic</fen>, created by an <fen>Author</fen> at the <fen>Time_of_creation</fen>. It may be a physical entity that is made of a certain <fen>Material</fen> etc. It may be constructed for an <fen>Honoree</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Author
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Author</fen> is the person who produced a particular <fen>Text</fen>.
<ex>I'm glad I bought and read <fex name="Author">Robbins's</fex> <t>book</t>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Text
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Text</fen> is the entity that contains linguistic information.
<ex>I'm glad I bought and read Robbins's <fex name="Text"><t>book</t></fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Honoree
FE.definition: <def-root>The person for whom the <fen>Text</fen> is produced. <ex>The <fex name="Text"><t>poem</t></fex> <fex name="Hon">for Caitlin</fex> was included in an anthology .</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Time_of_creation
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Text</fen> was created.
<ex>Jackson's new story is based on a <fex name="Time_of_creation">1980</fex> <t>novel</t> by his father.</ex> <ex><t>Poems</t> <fex name="Time_of_creation">from the end of that dynasty</fex> are known to contain many novel metric structures.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Material
FE.definition: <def-root>What a <fen>Text</fen> is made of (if applicable). <ex>The library was so old, it was filled with <fex name="Mat">vellum</fex> <fex name="Text"><t>tomes</t></fex>, not a paperback in sight.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Containing_text
FE.definition: <def-root>This is a text in which the <fen>Text</fen> is located. <ex>The last <fex name="Text"><t>poem</t></fex> <fex name="Cont_text">in the anthology</fex> was horrid.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Genre
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Genre</fen> or sub-<fen>Genre</fen> of the <fen>Text</fen>.
<ex>She writes only <fex name="Genre">historical</fex> <fex name="Text"><t>fiction</t></fex>.</ex>
<ex>I've got three <fex name="Genre">comedic</fex> <fex name="Text"><t>screenplays</t></fex> on my desk right now!</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Use
FE.definition:
<def-root>The use for which the text was produced; its purpose.
<ex>She read through the bicycle's <fex name="Use">construction</fex> <fex name="Text"><t>manual</t></fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Components
FE.definition: <def-root>The smaller texts that make up the <fen>Text</fen>. <ex>He found it in a <fex name="Text"><t>book</t></fex> <fex name="Cmpnt">of spells</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Topic
FE.definition: <def-root><fen>Topic</fen> is what the <fen>Text</fen> is about.<ex>I read a <fex name="Text"><t>book</t></fex> <fex name="Topic">about knitting</fex>.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Title
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Title</fen> of a <fen>Text</fen>.
<ex>She read <fex name="Title">Sassy</fex> <fex name="Text"><t>magazine</t></fex>.</ex> <ex>Current NOW President Kim Gandy said Friedan's <fex name="Title">Feminine Mystique</fex> <t>book</t> opened women's eyes.</ex>
NOTE: when the <fen>Title</fen> is expressed in an appositive clause, it is labeled as <fen>Text</fen> on the first layer and <fen>Title</fen> on the second.
<ex>She read the <t>magazine</t> <fex name="Text">Sassy</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Medium
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Medium</fen> is the language in which a text is composed, or the physical medium (radio, ink) in which it is distributed.
<ex>Science <fex name="Text"><t>articles</t></fex> <fex name="Medium">in Greek</fex> are difficult to understand for me.</ex>
<ex>It's prudent to pay attention to <fex name="Medium">radio</fex> <t>bulletins</t>.</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: tome.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: chiefly humorous a book, especially a large, scholarly one.

lexUnit.name: fanzine.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a small, independent magazine put out by the devotees of a particular subculture.

lexUnit.name: epilogue.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 1.a section or speech at the end of a book or play serving as a comment on or a conclusion to what has happened.

lexUnit.name: benediction.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: words of blessing.

lexUnit.name: imprecation.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: formal a spoken curse.

lexUnit.name: eulogy.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 1. a speech or piece of writing that praises someone highly.

lexUnit.name: autobiography.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an account of a person's life written by that person.

lexUnit.name: ballad.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a poem or song narrating a popular story in short stanzas.

lexUnit.name: biography.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an account of someone's life written by someone else.

lexUnit.name: chronicle.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: written account of important or historical events in the order of their occurrence.

lexUnit.name: comedy.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 2. a play with a humorous or satirical tone, in which the characters ultimately triumph over adversity.

lexUnit.name: diary.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 1. a book in which one keeps a daily record of events and experiences.

lexUnit.name: drama.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a play.

lexUnit.name: elegy.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 1. a mournful poem, typically a lament for the dead.

lexUnit.name: epic.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 1.a long poem narrating the deeds of heroic or legendary figures or the past history of a nation.

lexUnit.name: epigram.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 2.a short witty poem.

lexUnit.name: epistle.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a letter.

lexUnit.name: essay.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 1. a piece of writing on a particular subject.

lexUnit.name: exemplum.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: pl. exempla an example or model, especially a moralizing or illustrative story.

lexUnit.name: fable.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a short story, typically with animals as characters, conveying a moral

lexUnit.name: festschrift.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: pl. Festschriften or Festschrifts a collection of writings published in honour of a scholar.

lexUnit.name: haiku.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: pl. same or haikus a Japanese poem of seventeen syllables, in three lines of five, seven, and five.

lexUnit.name: letter.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 2. a written, typed, or printed communication, sent by post or messenger.

lexUnit.name: limerick.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 1.a humorous five-line poem with a rhyme scheme aabba.

lexUnit.name: lyric.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: also lyrics the words of a song.

lexUnit.name: memoir.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a historical account or biography written from personal knowledge

lexUnit.name: monograph.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 1.a detailed written study of a single specialized subject.

lexUnit.name: mystery.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a novel, play, or film dealing with a puzzling crime.

lexUnit.name: novel.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 1.a fictitious prose narrative of book length.

lexUnit.name: novelette.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: chiefly derogatory a short novel, typically a light romantic one.

lexUnit.name: novella.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 1.a short novel or long short story.

lexUnit.name: ode.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 1. a lyric poem, typically in the form of an address, written in varied or irregular metre.

lexUnit.name: poetry.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: mass noun poems collectively or as a genre of literature.

lexUnit.name: poem.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: .a literary composition that is given intensity by particular attention to diction (sometimes involving rhyme), rhythm, and imagery.

lexUnit.name: rhyme.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: rhyming poetry or verse

lexUnit.name: saga.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a long story of heroic achievement, especially a medieval prose narrative in Old Norse or Old Icelandic.

lexUnit.name: song.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a short poem or other set of words set to music.

lexUnit.name: sonnet.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 1.a poem of fourteen lines using any of a number of formal rhyme schemes, in English typically having ten syllables per line. [Prosody]

lexUnit.name: speech.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a formal address delivered to an audience.

lexUnit.name: tetralogy.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a group of four related literary or operatic works.

lexUnit.name: thriller.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 1.a novel, play, or film with an exciting plot, typically involving crime or espionage.

lexUnit.name: tragedy.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a serious play with an unhappy ending, especially one concerning the downfall of the protagonist.

lexUnit.name: trilogy.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: pl. -ies a group of three related novels, plays, films, etc.

lexUnit.name: whodunit.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a mystery.

lexUnit.name: manual.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 1. a book giving instructions or information.

lexUnit.name: handbook.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 1. a book giving brief information such as basic facts on a particular subject or instructions for operating a machine.

lexUnit.name: paperback.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 1. a book bound in stiff paper or flexible card.

lexUnit.name: hardback.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a book bound in stiff covers.

lexUnit.name: grimoire.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a book of magic spells and invocations.

lexUnit.name: spellbook.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a book of magical spells.

lexUnit.name: lay.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a short lyric or narrative poem meant to be sung

lexUnit.name: book.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a written or printed work consisting of pages glued or sewn together along one side and bound in covers

lexUnit.name: magazine.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a periodical publication containing articles and illustrations.

lexUnit.name: account.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 1. a description of an event or experience.

lexUnit.name: sermon.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: 1. a talk on a religious or moral subject, especially one given during a church service and based on a passage from the Bible.

lexUnit.name: tract.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a short treatise in pamphlet form, typically on a religious subject

lexUnit.name: screenplay.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the script of a film, including acting instructions and scene directions.

lexUnit.name: script.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the written text of a play, film, or broadcast.

lexUnit.name: article.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a piece of writing included with others in a newspaper or magazin

lexUnit.name: obituary.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a notice of a person's death in a newspaper or periodical, typically including a brief biography.

lexUnit.name: volume.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a book forming part of a work or series

lexUnit.name: mag.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a magazine.

lexUnit.name: edition.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a particular form or version of a published text.

lexUnit.name: treatise.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a written work dealing formally and systematically with a subject.

lexUnit.name: report.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an account given of a matter after investigation or consideration.

lexUnit.name: bulletin.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a short official statement or summary of news.

lexUnit.name: tractate.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a treatise.

lexUnit.name: hagiography.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the writing of the lives of saints.

lexUnit.name: journal.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a newspaper or magazine dealing with a particular subject.

lexUnit.name: periodical.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a periodical magazine or newspaper.

lexUnit.name: editorial.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a newspaper article giving an opinion on a topical issue

lexUnit.name: meditation.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a discourse expressing considered thoughts on a subject.

lexUnit.name: booklet.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a small, thin book with paper covers.

lexUnit.name: fiction.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: prose literature, especially novels, describing imaginary events and people.

lexUnit.name: writings.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: books or other written works.

lexUnit.name: missive.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a letter.

lexUnit.name: newspaper.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a printed publication, typically issued daily or weekly, consisting of folded unstapled sheets and containing news, articles, and advertisements.

lexUnit.name: list.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a number of connected items or names written consecutively.

lexUnit.name: manuscript.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a handwritten book, document, or piece of music.

lexUnit.name: literature.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: written works, especially those regarded as having artistic merit.

lexUnit.name: history.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a continuous, typically chronological, record of past events or trends.

lexUnit.name: brochure.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a small, free catalogue of information used for marketing purposes.

lexUnit.name: material.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: literature on a topic

lexUnit.name: pamphlet.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a short booklet meant to disseminate basic or introductory information.

lexUnit.name: issue.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: part of a series of a periodical

lexUnit.name: paper (newspaper).n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a newspaper or other regular publication

lexUnit.name: paper (article).n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a (typically scholarly) written work that is usually intended for a class or publication in a journal

lexUnit.name: epic.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: of or relating to poetry of the epic tradition.
